Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT13-COX 
    

 UPDATE      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 13, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   Eds. Adds: DDN-DEATHMAIN, RUBYDEE, JOEMURRAY-COLUMN,
OLY-LUEPNITZ;

   Deletes: PRIVACY, DESTINATION-MIR

   INTERNATIONAL

   EUROPE-FUEL _ LONDON _ Protests over high fuel prices
intensified across Europe on Tuesday as demonstrations snarled
traffic and cut services. The protests were especially fierce in
Britain, where Prime Minister Tony Blair was standing firm against
tax cuts during the biggest political crisis of his tenure.
(Roughton, Cox News Service). 25.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category International, subcategory
Other.

   NATIONAL

   GORE _ MIDDLETOWN, Ohio _ Live coverage of Vice President Gore
campaigning in Middletown, Ohio. Gore visits Middletown High
School. (Middletown Journal).

   SUBLIMINAL-AD _ A look at the subliminal advertising claims and
counterclaims over the years: how they work, do they work and what
do the political experts (pro and con) in the field say about them.
The ads have come a long way since Kevin Nealon's old skit on
Saturday Night Live. George W. Bush on Tuesday dismissed as
``bizarre and weird'' an allegation that a Republican Party ad
criticizing his opponent's Medicare plan contained the hidden word
``rat'' as a subliminal message. ``They'll read everything into
anything,'' Bush said of his Democratic opponents during a stop in
West Palm Beach, Fla. (Scott, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 25
inches.

   CLINTON-CONGRESS _ WASHINGTON _ President Clinton meets Tuesday
at the White House with congressional leaders of both parties in a
session that could shape the results of Congress's final few weeks.
(Deans, Cox News Service). 25.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National, subcategory, U.S.
Government.

   SELMA-VOTE _ SELMA, Ala. - Live coverage of the election in
Selma where Mayor Joe Smitherman - who has been in office for 35
years - is in a tight race. (Manuel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WRIGHT-FLYER _ WASHINGTON _ The National Air and Space museum,
The National Park Service and EAA, an recreational aviation
organization, hold a news conference to announce plans for a
celebration the 100th anniversary of powered flight by the Wright
Brothers. The showpiece of the program is the construction and
flight of an accurate Wright Flyer reproduction. (Gaffney, Dayton
Daily News). 22. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National, subcategory, U.S.
Government.

   HOUSING _ WASHINGTON--Housing and Urban Development Secretary
Andrew Cuomo announced a new $100 million program in which rental
vouchers can be used to purchase homes. (Doyle, Cox News Service)

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   BUSH _ GWBush appeared off message again Tuesday after
complaints that an RNC television ad contained a subliminal message
about Vice President Al Gore. Bush denied the charge, adding that
the spot was coming off the air Tuesday. (Herman, Austin
American-Statesman)

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) MOVED.

   WOMENWORK _ State commission announces Florida's best employers
for working women. And the winner in the big private employer
category is _ Cross Country Staffing of Boca. (Smith, Palm Beach
Post)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   JOEMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ We have a new restaurant _
this in a town that uses the term loosely. McDonald's, for
instance, is a considered a drive-in restaurant. But Marbles, the
new place, is a fine dining, uptown-style establishment that just
happens to be located in a downtown basement. But, it's the best
basement Lufkin has to offer. (Joe Murray, Cox News Service).
MOVED.

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ Despite all the strides we have made in
uncovering the secrets of the Earth, we continue to discover new
pieces of the geologic and human puzzle. The latest is an ancient
city in a Guatemalan jungle. (Teepen, Cox News Service.) MOVED
MONDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ Howard Kleinber's Wednesday column is not
available this week. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ Last month the cat took
sick. She's well now, but I'm scheduled for counseling. The vet
recommended it. My feelings weren't hurt nor was I surprised that
Doc had so quickly diagnosed the secondary problem. After all, he'd
done just fine with the first. Biddy was suffering from a urinary
tract irritation. Antibiotics and a change of diet cleared that up.
My ailment, on the other hand, is much more complicated. In fact, I
suspect the medication has not yet been discovered that will
prevent a 10-pound ball of fur from reducing an otherwise stable
adult to a babbling psychotic who jumps to every meow. (Schuett,
Cox News Service) MOVED.

   YOUNG-COLUMN _ Texas Sen. Phil Gramm wants to put Ronald
Reagan's likeness on a coin. I say give that man a nickel. (Young,
Waco Tribune-Herald)

   BUSINESS

   IXL-ELLIS-QA _ Question and answer with Bert Ellis, founder,
chairman and CEO of IXL Enterprises. Conversation centers around
Ellis' plans to turn iXL around from current financial and
personnel problems. 9atz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution), 40.

   WEB-REGS _ FCC Chairman speaks to telecom conference in Atlanta
about Internet regulations. (Kanell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
15.

   BOBBIN-SHOW _ The Bobbin Show, the world's largest sewn products
trade show, comes again to the Georgia World Congress Center Sept.
13-15. This year, besides the usual emphasis on the latest
technology, is a new attention to how manufacturers can forge
tax-advantageous alliances with Latin America and the Caribbean.
(Harte, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 10.

   GAPACIFIC-SUIT _ Caraustar Industries has sued Georgia-Pacific,
saying that reduced gypsum orders are a violation of a contract
between the companies and will lead to a pretax reduction in
Caraustar's third quarter operating income of $2 million to $2.9
million. The company expects the declining orders to reduce third
quarter earnings by 5 cents to 7 cents a share. In addition,
Caraustar said lower orders will force it to immediately close its
Camden, N.J., mill, which will result in a charge of about $6
million. (Bond, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MONEYTALK _ Personal finance advice. This week: Handling debt.
(Ezell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   E-BUSINESS _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting Business readers. Today: (Seward,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   LIFESTYLE

   GETAWAY-ASHEVILLE _ ASHEVILLE, N.C. _ Not all mountain crafts
traditions are serious. Consider the Gee Haw Whimmy Diddle Contest
during Heritage Weekend, Sept. 15-17 at the Folk Art Center of the
Southern Highland Craft Guild in Asheville, N.C. This 20th annual
contest, pure whimsy for the whole family, is based on skill in
operating a handmade mountain toy of two sticks of whittled
rhododendron and a propeller. The object is to slide one stick
against the other until the propeller turns. Lots of people of all
ages turn out to participate or cheer. Also at the fest:
storytelling, shaped-note singing and craft demonstrations.
(Laughinghouse, Cox News Service). 38

   OCTOGENS-WED _ 80-year-old and 85-year-old, who've known each
other for 50 years, finally tie the knot after former spouses fall
by the wayside. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTO.

   E-LIVING _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting arts, entertainment and leisure
activites. Today: (Footlick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   DDN-DEATHMAIN _ DAYTON, Ohio - Although she had complained of
pain in her shoulders and back for half a year, Sandi Hughes wasn't
diagnosed with lung cancer until the disease had reached her brain
and paralyzed her legs. At age 43, and with two adolescent
daughters in her sole care, Hughes suddenly had no job and no
family support system at a time when she was facing a terminal
disease. She called on her unemployed husband, from whom she had
been separated for six years. In May, he moved her from Alabama to
his home in Fairborn, where family members, especially Hughes'
15-year-old daughter, Jennifer, cared for her in a tiny, ramshackle
house. For hours at a time, Jennifer and her 12-year-old
half-sister, Stephanie, were alone in sharing for their mother and,
at times, had no food in the house. (Dayton Daily News). MOVED.

   DDN-VETS _ When he was just 18, Harold Johnson served his
country proudly in Vietnam as an infantry sergeant, only to be
exposed by his own government to a toxic chemical, Agent Orange,
that would kill him some 30 years later. Days before his death from
lung cancer last week, Johnson, 51, said he was no longer angry
about what had happened to him in Vietnam. The Dayton VA provides a
full range of end-of-life services to eligible veterans, at reduced
or no cost, depending on their eligibility. (Dayton Daily News).
19. WITH PHOTO. MOVED.

   EDs: This is Part 4 of Dayton's 'Letting Go' series.

   PSYCHOLOGY-LECRONE _ Dr. Hap LeCrone's weekly psychology column.
This week: Dentistphobia. (LeCrone, Waco Tribune-Herald) MOVED.

   ENTERTAINMENT-ARTS

   RUBYDEE _ Feature on Ruby Dee and her Oxford, Ohio exploits.
(Jones, Hamilton-Journal) MOVED.

   TV-RATINGS _ Weekly ratings, likely dominated by Emmys. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 14.

   SPORTS

   BASEBALL

   BBN-ALFONSECA _ Florida's Antonio Alfonseca is the best closer
that no one has heard of. He leads the National League in saves,
but didn't make the All-Star Game. In fact, if anyone has heard of
Alfonseca, it's because he had an extra finger on each hand.
(Stinson, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   OLYMPICS

   OLY-NUDES _ Jenny Thompson's decision to pose semi-nude in
Sports Illustrated touched off a debate on whether women athletes
should flash excessive American skin. Olympians can be found in
various stages of undress all over the newsstands. Others grin and
bare it on calendars that generate charitable contributions along
with either admiration or titillation, depending on your take.
(Tierney, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 35.

   OLY-SOCCER _ SYDNEY _ Advance men's soccer, U.S. vs. Czech
Republic. (Parker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLY-DELISHA-MILTON _ Georgia native Delisha Milton leads the
U.S. women's basketball team. (Rosen, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20.

   OLY-LUEPNITZ _ Glen Luepnitz remembers the moment when, out of
the blue, he received a call from Richar Quick, head coach for the
U.S. women's swim team. Quick, the former coach of the University
of Texas women's swim team, had heard about Luepnitz's work with
athletes while visiting a daughter in Austin. He asked Luepnitz if
he would consider working with some of Quick's swimmers and provide
advice on nutrition and supplements. ``I had just finished firing a
couple of my patients,'' Luepnitz recalled. ``I had great suspicion
they were cheating. So, I kind of read him the riot act. I told him
if I found athletes who were cheating, I would turn them in. And I
said if he knew they were cheating, I'd turn him in.'' When the
response was silence, Luepnitz figured the conversation, and the
opportunity, were    over. Quick finally said, ``Twenty-five years I
have been trying to find someone who would say that.'' Thus began
an unlikely partnership that has been extremely productive, even as
it has become somewhat controversial. A week ago, the Houston
Chronicle ran a story charging that Luepnitz had obtained his
doctorate at a diploma mill. (Maher, Austin American-Statesman)

   FOOTBALL/PROS

   FBN-FALCONS-DEFENSE _ The Falcons defensive strategy in the
first two games focused on applying pressure to the quarterback
with several blitz packages. But the strategy eventually backfired.
The Falcons allowed an average of 35 points in the two games and
needed 36 points in the opener to defeat San Francisco. Defensive
coordinator Rich Brooks admitted that the team will try a different
strategy Sunday against Carolina with less blitzing and more
traditional play. But will that be enough for the struggling unit?
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   FOOTBALL/COLLEGES

   FBC-AUBURN-RUDI _ SEC feature on Auburn running back Rudi
Johnson, a JUCO transfer who has burst on the scene this season.
Lede story on the Inside the SEC page. (Schlabach, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 14.

   FBC-TENN-QB _ Redshirt freshman A.J. Suggs has gone from
obscurity to starting quarterback for Tennessee, which plays
Florida on Saturday. (Barnhart, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 25.

   E-SPORTS _ A daily column featuring the most useful Web sites
and live online events affecting Sports fans. Today: (Greene,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   BASKETBALL

   COLLEGES

   BISHER-KNIGHT _ Furman Bisher column on Bob Knight. (Bisher,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WOODS-KNIGHT _ Column on Bobby Knight. (Woods, Palm Beach Post)

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor Todd C. Duncan, 404-526-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
